The Chapter with Nāgas and Samālas
The Elder’s Birth Story of the Giver of Grass Mats
“Not far from the Himalayas,
there was a great lake;
Covered with a hundred-petaled lotus,
with garlands of various birds.
Having bathed and drunk there,
we lived not far away;
I saw the foremost of ascetics,
going without faltering.
Knowing my thought,
the unsurpassed Teacher in the world;
Having descended from above,🔽stood on the ground for a moment.
Taking grass with my horn,
I gave it as a seat;
The Fortunate One sat there,
the leader of the three worlds.

analyzed: sakam cittam pasādetvā  avandi loka nāyaka
translated: Having gladdened my own mind,🔽I bowed to the leader of the world;
I was contemptuous and disrespectful,
desiring the great sage.
By that gladdening of mind,
I was reborn in a divine realm;
I do not know of a bad destination,
this is the fruit of the grass mat.
In the second eon from this,
I was a king called Migasammata;
Endowed with the seven treasures,
a powerful wheel-turning monarch.
The four analytical knowledges,🔽… and so on …

original: kataṁ buddhassa sāsanaṁ”.🔽Itthaṁ sudaṁ āyasmā tiṇasantharadāyako thero imā gāthāyo abhāsitthāti.
analyzed: katam buddhassa sāsana  ittham sudam āyasmā tiṇasantharadāyakaḥ theraḥ imāḥ gāthāyaḥ abhāsittha ati
translated: I have done the Teacher’s bidding.”🔽Thus has the Elder Tiṇasantharadāyaka related these verses.
The Story of the Elder Tiṇasantharadāyaka is finished.
